div.p: As it hath been often presented at Whitehall, by their majesty's servants; and after at the cockpit in Drury lane, with great applause.

Written by
John Foard and
Tho. Deckergent.
London, printed by I. bell, for Andrew Penneycuicke, anno Dom. 1656.

div.head: To the right honourable Thomas Wriathesley, Earl of Southampton, lord Wriathsley, of Tichfield, etc.
div.p:
Herodotus reports that the Egyptians by wrapping their dead in glass, presents them lively to all posterity; but your lordship will do more, by the vivifying beams of your acceptation, revive the parents of this orphan poem, and make them live to eternity. While the stage flourished, the poem lived by the breath of general applauses, and the virtual fervour of the court; but since hath languished
for want of heat, and now near shrunk up with cold, creeps (With a shivering fear) to extend it selse at the flames of your benignity. My lord, though it seems rough and forlorn, it is the issue of worthy parents, and we doubt not, but you will find it accomplished with their virtue. Be pleased then (My lord) to give it entertainment, the more destitute and needy it is, the greater reward may be challenged by your charity; and so being sheltered under your wings, and comforted by the sunshine of your favour, it will become proof against the injustice of time, and like one of Demetrius' statues appear fresher and fresher to all ages. My lord, were we not confident of the excellence of the piece, we should not dare to assume an impudence to prefer it to a person of your honour, and known judgement; whose hearts are ready sacrifices, to your name and honour, being my lord

closer.signed: Your lordship's most humble, and most obligedly, submissive servants, Theophilus bird. Andrew Penneycuicke.

div.head: Upon the sun's darling.
div.p: Is he then found? Phoebus make holiday; tie up thy steeds; and let the Cyclops play; Mulciber leave thy anvil, and be trim; comb thy black muzzle, be no longer grim; Mercury be quick, with mirth furnish the heavens, Jove, this day let all run at fix and sevens; and Ganymede be nimble, to the brim fill bouls of nectar, that the gods may swim, to solemnize their healths that did discover the obscure being of the sun's fond lover. That from the example of their liberal mirth we may enjoy like freedom on earth.

It is not here intended to present thee with the perfect analogy betwixt the world and man, which was made for man; nor their coexistence, the world determining with man this: I presume hath been by others treated on, but drawing the curtain of this moral , you shall find him in his progression as followeth.

lg.head: The first season.
lg.l: Present him in the twilight of his age
Nor pot-gun-proof, and, yet he'll have his page:
This small knight-errant will encounter things
Above his perch, and like the partridge springs.

lg.head: The second season.
lg.l: Folly, his squire, the lady humour brings.
Who in his ear far sweeter novels sings.
He follows them; forsakes the April Queen,
And now the noontide of his age is seen.

lg.head: The third season.
lg.l: As soon as nerved with strength, he becomes weak,
Folly and humour, doth his reason break;
Hurries him from his noontide to his even;
From summer to his 〈◊〉 he is driven.

lg.head: The fourth season.
lg.l: And now the winter, or his nonage takes him:
The sad remembrance of his errors wakes him;
Folly and humour, fain he'd cast away,
But they will never leave him, till he's clay.
Thus man as clay descends, ascends in spirit;
Dust, goes to dust, the soul unto it's merit.

div.head: Act. i.
div.stage: Enter the priest of the sun.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Let your tunes, you sweet-voiced spears,
Overtake him:
Charm his fancies, open his ears,
Now awake him. begin.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Fancies are but streams
Of vain pleasure:
They who by their dreams
True joys measure;
Feasting, starve; laughing, weep;
Playing smart, whilst in sleep
Fools with shadows smiling,
wake and and find
Hopes like wind,
Idle hopes beguiling.
Thoughts fly away, time hath past 'em
Wake now, awake, see and taste 'em.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: That I might ever slumber, and enjoy
Contents as happy as the soul's best wishes
Can fancy or imagine, 'tis a cruelty
Beyond example, to usurp the peace
I sat enthroned in, who was't plucked me from it.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Young man look hither.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Good; I envy not
The pomp of your high office; all preferment
Of earthly glories are to me diseases,
Infecting those found parts which should preserve
The flattering retribution to my thankfulness;
The times are better to me; there's no taste
Left on the palate of my discontent
To catch at empty hopes, whose only blessedness
Depends on being miserable.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Raybright
Thou drawst thy great descent from my grand patron the sun;
Whose priest I am.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: For small advantage;
He who is high-born never mounts von battlemen
Of sparkling stars, unless I be in spirit
As humble as the child of one that sweats
To eat the dear-earned bread of honest thrift.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Hast thou not flowed in honours?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Honours, I'd not be baited with my fears
Of losing 'em, to be their monstrous creature
An age together, 'tis beside as comfortable
To die upon the embroidery of the grass,
Unwound, as to sir a world at gaze,
Whilst from a pinnacle I tumble down
And break my neck, to be talked of, and wondered at.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: You have worn rich habits.
Fine ass-trappings.
A pedlar's heir turned gallant, follows fashion,
can by a cross-legged tailor be transformed
Into a jackanapes of passing bravery:
'Tis a stout happiness to wear good clothes,
Yet live and die a fool — mew.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: You have had choice
Of beauties to enrich your marriage-bed.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Monkeys and paraquitoes are as pretty
To play withal, though not indeed so gentle.
Honesty's indeed a fine jewel, but the Indies
Where it grows is hard to be discovered, troth sir
I care for no long travels with lost labour.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Pleasures of every sense have been your servants,
Whenas you've commanded them.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: To threaten ruin,
Corrupt the purity of knowledge, wrest
Desires of better life, to those of these
This scurvy one, this life scarce worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: 'Tis melancholy, and too fond indulgence
To your own dulled affections: sway your judgement,
You could not else be thus lost, or suspect
The care your ancestor the sun takes of ye.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The care, the scorn he throw; on me.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Fie, fie;
Have you been sent out into strange lands,
Seen courts of foreign Kings, by them been graced,
To bring home such neglect.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I have reason for't.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Pray show it.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Since my coming home I have found
More sweets in one unprofitable dream,
Then in my lives whole pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: Your fantasy
Misleads your judgement vainly, sir in brief
I am to tell you, how I have received
From your progenitor, my lord, the sun,
A token, that he visibly will descend
From the celestial orb to gratify
All your wild longings.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Very likely, when pray:
the world the whiles shall be beholding to him
For a long night, new married men will curse,
Though their brides tickle for't, o! candle and lanthorn
Will grow to an excessive rate i'th city.

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: These are but flashes of a brain disordered.
Contain your float of spleen in seemly bounds,
Your eyes shall be your witness.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: He may come.

div.stage: Enter time with a whip, whipping Follie before him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Hence, hence, thou shame of nature, mankind's foil:
Time whips thee from the world, kicks thee, and scorns thee.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Whip me from the world, why whip? am I a dog, a cur,
A mongrel: baw waw. Do thy worst, I defy thee.

lg.head: Sings.
lg.l: I will roar and squander,
Cousin, and be drunk too;
I will maintain my pander,
Keep my horse, and p●nok too;
Brawl and scuffle,
Shifted and shuffle,
Swagger in my potmeals:
Dams rank with;
Do mad prank with
Roaring boars and oatmeals,
Pox a time, I care not,
Being passed 'tis nothing:
I le be free and spare not ▪
Sorrows are lives 〈◊〉:
Melancholy
Is but folly,
Mirth and youth are plotters.
Time go hang thee,
I will bang thee,
Though I die in co●●ers.

sp.p:
And what think you of this, you old doting moth-eaten bearded 〈◊〉 as I am folly by the mother's side, and a time-bred gentleman, I will sing thee to death, i● thou 〈◊〉 me; cannot a man of fashion, for 〈◊〉, put on now and then his
working-day robes of humility, but he must presently be subject to a beadle's rod of correction; go mend thyself cannibal, 'tis not without need, I am sure the times were never more beggarly and proud, waiting-women flaunt it in cast-suits, and their ladies fall for 'em; knaves over-brave wise men, while wise men ●and with cap and knee to fools: pitiful time! pitiful

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: Out foul, prodigious, and abortive birth;
Behold the sand glass of thy days is broke

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Bring me another, I'll shatter that too.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: No; thou'st misspent thy hours, lavish fool, like
The circuit of thy life, in ceaseless riots
It is not therefore fit that thou shouldst live
In such a court as the sun's majesty
Vouchsafes to illuminate with his bright beams.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: In any court, father baldpate, where my granam the moon shows her horns, except the consistory court, and there she need not appear; cuckolds carry such sharp stilettoes in their foreheads, I'll live here and laugh at the bravery of ignorance, maugre thy scurvy and abominable beard.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.l: Priest of the sun 'tis near about the minute,
Thy patron will descend, scourge hence this trifle;
Time is never lost, till in the common schools
Of impudence, time meets with wilful fools.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Farewell 1538, I might have said five thousand, but the others long enough a conscience to be honest conditioned, pox on him; it's a notable railing whipper, of a plain time whipper.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: You heard the charge he left.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Ay, ay, a may give a charge, 'a has been a petty court holder ever since he was a minute old, he took you for a foreman of a jury

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Pray sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: No matter what, what are you?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Not as you are, I thank my better fates,
I am grand child to the sun.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: And I am cousin germane, some two or three hundred removes off, to the moon, and my name is folly.

sp.speaker: Ray,
sp.l: Folly, sir of what quality?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p:
Quality; any quality in fashion: drinking, whoring, singing, dancing, dicing, swearing, roaring 〈◊〉 oisting, lying ▪
cogging, canting, lcetero, will you have any more.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: You have a merry heart, if you can guide it.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Yes faith; so, so, I laugh not at those whom I fear, I fear not those whom I love, and I love not any whom I laugh not at, pretty strange humour, is't not?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: To any one that knows you not, it is.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: You must a void.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Away away, I have no such meaning indeed-la.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Hark the fair hour is come, draw to the altar,
And with amazement , reverence, and comfort
Behold the broad eyed lamp of heaven descending, — stand —

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: O brave!

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Stand.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Glorious and bright, lo here we bend
Before thy throne, trembling, attend
Thy sacred pleasures, be pleased then
To shower thy comforts down, that men
May freely taste in life's extremes
The influence of thy powerful dreams.

sp.speaker: Roy.
sp.l: Let not my fate too swiftly run,
Till thou acknowledge me thy sun.
O there's no joy even from the womb,
Of frailty: till we be called home.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Now am I an arrant rascal, and cannot speak one word for myself, if I were hanged.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Raybright.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: It calls ye, answer.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Lord and father.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: We know thy cares, appear to give release,
Boldly make thy demands, for we will please
To grant whate'er thou sayest for ▪

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Fair beamed sir;
I dare not greedily prefer
Eternity of earth's delights,
Before that duty which invites
My filial piety, in this
Your love shall perfect my heart's bliss;
if I, but for one only year,
Enjoy the several pleasures here,
With every season in his kind,
Can bless a mortal with.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: I find
Thy reason breeds thy appetite, and grant it
Thou masterest thy desire, and shall not want it;
To the spring garden let him be conveyed,
And entertained there by that lovely maid:
All the varieties the spring can show,
Be subject to his will.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: Lights lord, we go.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And I will follow, that am not in love with such fopperies.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: We must descend, and leave a while our sphere
To greet the world — ha, there does now appear
A circle in this round, of beams that shine,
As if their friendly lights would darken mine:
No let 'em shine out still, for these are they,
By whose sweet favours, when our warmths decay,
Even in the storms of winter, daily nourish
Our active motions, which in summer flourish
By their fair quickening dews of noble loves:
O may you all like stars, whilst swift time moves,
Stand fixed in firmaments of blessed contents:
Meanwhile recreations we present,
Shall strive to please; I have the foremost tract;
Each season else begins and ends an act.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter spring, Raybright, youth, health and delight.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Welcome the mother of the year, the spring;
That mother on whose back age never can sit.
For age still waits upon her that spring the nurse;
Whose milk the summer sucks, and is made wanton.
Physician to the sick, strength to the sound;
By whom all things above, and underground
Are quickened with new heat, fresh blood, brave vigour,
That spring on thy fair cheeks, in kisses lays
Ten thousand welcomes, free as are those rays
From which thy name thou borrowest: glorious name!
Raybright, as bright in person as in 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Your eyes amazed me first, but now mine ears
Feel your tongues charms, in you move all the spheres.
Ch lady! would the sun, which gave me life,
Had never sent me to you.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Why! all my veins
Shrink up, as if cold winter were come back,
And with his frozen beard have numbed my lips
To hear that sigh fly from you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Round about me
A firmament of such full blessings shine,
I in your sphere seem a star more divine
Than in my father's chariot; should I ride
One year about the world in all his pride.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: O that sweet breath revives me! if thou never
Partest hence (As part thou shalt not) be happy ever.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I know I shall.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Thou to buy, whose state?
King's would lay down their crowns, fresh youth wait,
I charge thee, on my darling.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Madam I shall,
And on his smooth check such sweet roses set,
You still shall sit to gather then, and when
Their colours fade, brave shall spring again.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Thou (Without whom they that have hills of gold
Are slaves and wretches) health that canst nor be sold
Nor bought, I charge thee make his heart a tower
Guarded, for there lies the spring's paramour.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: One of my hands is writing still in heaven,
(For that's health's library) tother on the earth
Is physics treasurer, and what wealth those lay
Up for my Queen, all shall his will obey ▪

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Mortality sure falls from me ▪

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Thou! to whose tunes
The five nice senses dance; thou that dost spin
Those golden threads all women love to wind,
And but for whom, man would cut off mankind.
Delight not base, but noble, touch thy lyre,
And fill my court with brightest Delphic fire.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Hover, you winged musicians, in the air;
Clouds leave your dancing, no winds stir but fair.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Leave blustering march —

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: What bird so sings, yet so does wail,
'Tis Philomel the nightingale;
Jug, jug, jug, terve she cries,
And hating earth, to heaven she flies — cuckoo.
Ha, ha, hark, hark, the cuckoos sing
Cuckoo, to welcome in the spring.
Brave pricksong; who is't now we hear!
'Tis the lark's silver leer a leer:
Chirup the sparrow flies away;
For he fell to't ere break of day.
Ha, ha, hark, hark, the cuckoos sing
Cuckoo, to welcome in the spring.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: How does my sun-born sweetheart like his Queen;
Her court, her train.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Wondrous, such never were seen.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Fresher and fresher pastimes, one delight
Is a disease to th'wanton appetite.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Music take echoes voice, and dance quick rounds to thine own times in repercussive sounds.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Enough? I will not weary thee, pleasures change ▪
Thou, as the sun in a free zodiac range. —

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: A company of rural fellows, faced
Like lovers of your laws, beg to be graced
Before your highness, to present their sport ▪

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: A morris.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Give them our court:
stay, these dull birds may make thee stop thine ear,
Take thou my lightning, none but laurel here
Shall scape thy blasting; whom thou wilt confound
Smite; let those stand, who in thy choice sit crowned.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Let these then, I may surfeit else on sweets.
Sound sleeps do not still lie in princes' sheets.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Beckon the rurals in, the country-gray
Seldom ploughs treason, shouldst thou be stolen away.
By great ones, that's my fear.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Fear it not lady;
Should all the world's black sorceries be laid
To blow me hence, I move not.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: I am made
In that word the earth's empress —
Are not these sports too rustic?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: No; pretty and pleasing.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: My youngest girl, the violet-breathing may,
Being told by Flora that my love dwelled here,
Is come to do you service, will you please
To honour her arrival.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I shall attend.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: On them, and bid my rosy-fingered may
Rob hills and dales, with sweets to strew his way.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: An empress, sayest thou, fallen in love with me.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: She's a great woman, and all great women wish to be empresses; her name, the lady humour.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Strange name, I never saw her, knew her not:
What kind of creature is she?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Creature! of a skin soft as pomatum, sleek as jelly, white as blanched almonds; no mercer's wife ever handled yard with a prettier breath; sweet as a monkey's; lips of cherries, teeth of pearl, eyes of diamond, foot and leg as —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: And what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: 'Tis but a folly to tell it, my name is folly.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Fumor and folly; to my listening ear
Thy lady's praises often have been sung,
The trumpet sounding forth her graceful beauties.
Kindles high flames within me to behold her.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: She's as hot as you for your heart.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: This lady, called the spring, is an odd trifle.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: A green sickness thing, I came by the way of a hobby-horse letter of attorney, sent by my lady as a spy to you: spring a hot lady, a few fields and garden's lass, can you feed upon salads and tanzies, eat like an ass upon grass every day at my ladies, coms to you now a goose, now a woodcock, nothing but fowl; fowl pies, platters all covered with foul, and is not fowl very good fare?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yea marry is't sir, the fowl being kept clean.
My admiration wastes itself in longings
To see this rare piece, I'll see her; what are Kings, were not their
Pleasures varied; shall not mine then? should day
Last ever, 'twould be loathed as night.
Change is the sauce that sharpens appetite;
The way, I'll to her.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: The way is windy and narrow; for look you, I do but wind this cornet, and if another answer it, she coms.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Be quick then —

div.stage: Enter humour, a soldier, a Spaniard, an Italian dance, a French tailor.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Is this that slower the spring so dotes upon?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: This is that honeysuckle, she sticks in her ruff.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: A bedfellow for a fairy.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Admired perfection!
You let my praises to so high a tune,
My merits cannot reach 'em.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: My heartstrings shall then,
As mine eye gives that sentence on thy person;
And never was mine eye a corrupt judge,
That judge to save thee would condemn a world,
And lose mankind to gain thee; 'tis not the spring ▪
With all her gawdy arbours, nor perfumes
Sent up in flattering incense to the sun,
For shooting glames at her, and for sending
Whole quires of singers to her every morn,
With all her amorous fires, can heat thy blood
As I can with one kiss.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The rose-lipped dawning
Is not so melting, so delicious.
Turn me into a bird that I may sit
Still singing in such boughs.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: What bird?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: A ringtail.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Thou shalt be turned to nothing but to mine,
My mine of pleasures which no hand shall rifle
But this, which in warm nectar baths the palm:
Invent some other tires; music; stay; none

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Heyday.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: New gowns, fresh fashions, I am not brave enough
To make thee wonder at me.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Not the moon
Riding at midnight in her crystal chariot,
With all her courtiers in their robes of stars
Is half so glorious.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: This feather was a bird of paradise,
Shall it be yours.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: No kingdom buys it from me.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Being in fools paradise he must not lose his bauble.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I am wrapped.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: In your mother's smock.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am wrapped above man's being, in being sphered
In such a globe of rarities, but say lady
What these are that attend you.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: All my attendants
Shall be to the sworn servants.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Folly is sworn to him already, never to leave him.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: He.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: A French gentleman that trails a Spanish pike. A tailor.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: We monsieur, heigh nimbla upon de cross caper, me take a de measure of de body from de top a de noddle to de heel and great toe, o stish de fine: dis collar is cut out in anger scurvy, ohais beeshes pincha de bum, me put one French yard into de toder●ose.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: N. French yards, they want a yard at least.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Shall I be brave then?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Golden as the sun.

sp.speaker: R●.
sp.l: What's he that looks so smickly?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p:
A flounder in a frying-pan, still skipping, one that loves
mutton so well, he always carries capers about him; his brains lie in his legs, and his legs serve him to no other use then to do tricks, as if he had bought 'em of a juggler, he's an Italian dancer, his name —

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.p: Signior Lavolta (Messer mio) me tesha all de bella corantoes, galliardaes, piamettaes, capeorettaes, amorettas dolche dolche to declamante do bona robaes de tuscana.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I never shall be so nimble.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Yes, if you power quicksilver into your shinbones, as he does.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: This now?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: A most sweet Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: A confecianador, which in your tongue is, a comfit-maker of Toledo, I can teach sugar to slip down your throat a million of ways.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And the throat has but one in all, o Toledo!

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.p: In conserves, candies, marmalades, sinkadoes, ponadoes, marablane, bergamo●u, aranxues muria, lemons, berengenas of Toledo, oriones, potatoes of Malage, and ten millions more.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Now 'tis ten millions, a Spaniard can multiply.

sp.speaker: Spa.
sp.l: I am your servitor.

sp.speaker: Rey.
sp.l: My palate pleased to what's this last?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: I am a gun that can roar, two stilettoes in one sheath, I can fight and bounce too, my lady by me, presents this sword and belt to you

sp.speaker: Ray
sp.l: 〈◊〉 mistress.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Put 〈◊〉 on.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.p: I'll drill you how to give the lie, and stab in the punto, if you dare not fight, then how to vamp a rotten quarrel without ado.

sp.speaker: Ray ▪
sp.l: How: dare not fight! there's in me the sun's fire.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: No more of this, dances awake the music ▪
Oyes! Music!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: No more of this, this sword arms me for battle.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Come then, let thou and I rise up in arms,
The field embraces, kisses our alarms.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: A dancer and a sailor, yet stand still: strike up-dance.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Oh! thou enticing strumpet, how durst thou
throw thy voluptuous spells about a temple
That's consecrate to me.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Poor spring, goody herbwife;
How dar'st thou cast a glance on this rich jewel
I ha' bought for mine own wearing.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Bought! art thou sold then?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yes, with her gifts, she buys me with her graces.

sp.speaker: Heal.
sp.l: Graces! A witch.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: What can she give thee.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: All things.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Which I for one bubble cannot add a sea too.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And show him a hobby-horse in my likeness.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: My Raybright, hear me; I regard not these.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What dowry can you bring me?

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Dowry! ha! is't come to this? am I held poor and base?
A girdle make, whose buckles stretched toth' length
Shall reach from th'arctic to th'antarctic pole:
What ground soever thou canst with that enclose
I'll give thee freely, not a lark that calls
The morning up, shall build on any turf
But she shall be thy tenant, call thee lord,
And for her rent pay thee in change of songs.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I must turn birdcatcher.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Do you think to have him for a song?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Live with me still; and all the measures
Played to by the spheres, I'll teach thee;
Let's but thus dally, all the pleasures
The moon beholds, her man shall reach thee.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Divinest!

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Here's a lady.

sp.speaker: Spring
sp.l: Is't come to who gives most?
The self same bay tree into which was turned:
Peneian Daphne, I have still kept green;
That tree shall now be thine, about it sit:
All the old poets with fresh laurel crowned,
Singing in verse the praise of chastity;
Hither when thou shalt come, they all shall rise,
Sweet cantoes of thy love, and mine to sing:
and invoke none but thee as Delian King.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Live by singing ballets?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Oh! base, turn poet, I would not be one myself.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Dwell in mine arms, aloft we'll hover,
And see fields of armies fighting:
Oh! part not from me, I will discover
There, all but books of fances writing;

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Not far off stands the Hipocrenian well,
Whither I'll lead thee, and but drinking there,
To welcome thee, nine muses shall appear:
And with full bowls of knowledge thee inspire.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Hang knowledge, drown your muse.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Ay, ●, or they'll drown themselves in sack and claret

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Do not regard their toys,
Be but my darling, age to free thee
From her curse, shall fall a dying;
Call me their empress; time to see thee
Shall for get his art of flying.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Oh! my all excellence.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Speak thou for me; I am fainting.

sp.speaker: Heal.
sp.l: Leave her, take this and travel, tell the world
I'll bring thee in to all the courts of Kings;
Where thou shalt stay, and learn their languages;
Kiss ladies, revel out the nights in dancing:
The day, manly pastimes; snatch from time
His glass, and let the golden sands run forth
As thou shalt jog them, riot it, go brave;
Spend half a world, my Queen shall bear thee out:
Yet all this while, though thou climb hills of years,
Shall not one wrinkle sit upon thy brow,
Nor any sickness shake thee; youth and health,
As slaves, shall lackey by thy chariot wheels;
And who, for two such jeweller, would not sell
The East, and West Indies; both are thine, so that —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p:
All lies gallop o'er the world, and not grow old, nor be sick; a lie; one gallant went but into France last day, and was never his own man since, another stepped but into the low countries, and
was drunk dead under the table, another did but peep into England, and it cost him more in good morrows blown up to him under his window, by drums and trumpets, than his whole voyage, besides he run mad upon't.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Here's my last farewell, ride a long with me;
I'll raise by art, out of base earth, a palace;
Whither thyself, waving a crystal stream,
Shall call together the most glorious spirits
Of all the Kings that have been in the world;
And they shall come only to feast with thee.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Rare!

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: At one end of this palace shall be heard
That music which gives motion to the heaven;
And in the middle Orpheus shall sit and weep,
For sorrow that his Luce had not the charms
To bring his fair Eurydice from hell;
Then at another end —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I'll hear no more;
This ends your strife, you only I adore.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.l: Oh! I am sick at heart; unthankful man
'Tis thou hast wounded me, farewell, she is led in.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Farewell?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Health, recover her; sirrah youth, look to her.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: That bird that in her nest sleeps out the spring
May fly in summer, but with sickly wing.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I owe thee for this pill, doctor.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: The spring will die sure.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Leather?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: If she does, folly here is a kind of a foolish poet,
And he shall write her epitaph.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Against the morning
See it then writ, and I'll reward thee for it.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: It shall not need.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: 'Tis like it shall not need, this is your folly,

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: He shall be ever yours.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: I hope ever to be mine own folly,
He's one of our fellows.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: In triumph now I lead thee; no, be thou Cesar,
And lead me.

sp.speaker: R●y.
sp.l: Neither; we'll ride with equal state
Both in one chariot, since we have equal fate ▪

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Each do his office to this man your lord;
For though delight, and youth, and health should leave him,
This ivory gated palace shall receive him.

div.head: Actus tertius.,

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: O my dear love the spring, I am cheated of thee;
Thou hadst a body the four elements
Dwelled never in a fairer; a mind princely?
Thy language like thy fingers, musical.
How cool wert thou in anger, in thy diet
How temperate, and yet sumptuous; thou wouldst not waste
The weight of a sad violet in excess;
Yet still thy board had dishes numberless.
Dumb beasts even loved thee; once a young lark
Sat on thy hand, and gazing on thine eyes
Mounted and sung, thinking them moving skies —

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: I ha' done my lord: my muse has pumped hard for an epitaph upon the late departed spring, and here her lines spring up.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Read.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Read; so I will, pleas you to reach me your high ears.
sp.l: Here lies the blithe spring,
Who first taught birds to sing;
Yet in April herself fell a crying:
Then may growing hot
A sweating sickness she got,
And the first of June lay a dying.
Yet no month can say
But her merry daughter may
Stuck her coffin with flowers great plenty.
The cuckoo sung in verse
An epitaph o'er her hearse,
But assure you the lines were not dainty.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: No more are thine, thou idiot; hast thou none
To poison with thy nast jigs but mine,
My matchless frame of nature, creation's wonder,
Out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: I am not in't, if I were, you'd see but scurvily; you find fault as patrons do with books, to give nothing.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yes balled one, beastly base one, blockish away;
Vex me not fool, turn out a doors your roarer,
French tailor, and that Spanish gingerbread,
And your Italian skipper; then sir, yourself.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Myself! Carbonado me, bastinado me, strappado me, hang me, I'll not stir; poor folly, honest folly, jocundary folly forsake your lordship; no true gentleman hates me, and how many women are given daily to me (If I would take 'em) some not far off know; tailor gone, Spanish fig gone, all gone but I —

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: My waiters coited off by you, you flay them;
Whence come these thunderbolts, what furies haunt you?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: You.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: She!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yes, and thou.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Baw waw.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I shall grow old, diseased, and melancholy;
For you have robbed me both of youth and health,
And that delight my spring bestowed upon me:
But for you two, I should be wondrous good;
By you I have been cozened, baffled, and torn
From the embracements of the noblest creature.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Your spring.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Yes she, even she, only the spring:
One morning spent with her, was worth ten nights
With ten of the prime beauties in the world:
She was unhappy never, but in two sons,
March a rude roaring fool.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And April a whining puppy.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: But May was a fine piece.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Mirror of faces.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p:
Indeed may was a sweet creature, and yet a great raiser
of maypoles.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: When will you sing my praises thus?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Thy praises, that art a common creature.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Common!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.p: Yes, common: I cannot pass through any prince's court, through any country, camp, town, city, village, but up your name is cried, nay cursed; a vengeance on this your debauched humour.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: A vintner spoke those very words last night, to a company of roaring boys, that would not pay their reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: How many bastards hast thou?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: None.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: 'Tis a lie, be judge by this your squire else.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Squire! worshipful Mr. Folly.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The courtier has his humour, has he not folly?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Yes marry has he, folly; the courtier's humour is to be brave, and not pay for't; to be proud, and no man cares for't.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Brave ladies have their humours.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Who has to do with that, but brave lords.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Your citizens have brave humours.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Oh! but their wives have tickling humour.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Yet done.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Humour madam, if all are your bastards that are given to humour you, you have a company of as arrant rascals to your children, as ever went toth' gallows; a collier being drunk jostled a knight into the kennel, and cried 'twas his humour; the knight broke his coxcomb, and that was his humour.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: And yet you are not common.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: No matter what I am:
Rail, curse, be frantic, get you to the tomb
Of your rare mistress; dig up your dead spring
And lie with her, kiss her; me, have you lost ▪

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And I scorn to be found.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Stay: must I lose all comfort, dearest stay;
There's such a deal of magic in those eyes,
I'm charmed to kiss these only.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Are you so? kiss on, I'll be kissed some where I warrant.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I will not leave my folly for a world.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Nor I you for ten.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Nor thee my love, for worlds piled upon worlds.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: If ever for the spring you do but sigh, I take my bells.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: And I my hobby-horse, — will you be merry than, and jawfand.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: As merry as the cuckoos of the spring,

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Again.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: How lady, lies the way?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I'll be your convoy,
And bring you to the court of the sun's Queen,
(Summer a glorious and majestic creature)
Her face outshining the poor springs, as far
As a sunbeam does a lamp, the moon a star.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Such are the spheres I'd move in, attend: us folly.

sp.speaker: Ray ▪
sp.l: I muse, my nimble folly stays so long.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: He's quick enough of foot, and counts, I swear)
That minute cast away, not spent on you.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: His company is music, next to yours;
Both of you are a consort; and I, your tunes
Lull me asleep, and when I most am sad,
My sorrows vanish from me in soft dreams:
But how far must we travel, is it our motion
Puts us in this heat; or is the air
In love with us, it clings with such embraces,
It keeps us in this warmth,

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: This shows, her court
Is not far off, you covet so to see:
Her subjects seldom kindle needless fires,
The sun lends them his flames.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Has she rare buildings.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Magnificent and curious; every noon
The horses of the day bait there, whilst he
(Who in a golden chariot makes them gallop
In twelve hours o'er the world) alights a while,
To give a love-kiss to the summer Queen.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: And shall we have fine sights there?

sp.speaker: Hn.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: And hear more ravishing music?

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: All the quiristers
That learned to sing i'th temple of the spring;
But her attain such cunning, that when the winds
Roar and are mad, and clouds in antic gambols
Dance o'er our head, their voices have such charms,
They'll all stand still to listen —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: I sweat like a pampered jade of Asia, and drop like a cob-nut out of Africa —

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Back: whither go you?
Oyes! this way.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: None must pass:
Here's kept no open court; our Queen this day
Rides forth a hunting, and the air being hot,
She will not have rude throngs to stifle her — back

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: And did break her heart then ▪

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Yes with disdain.

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: The heart of my dear mother nurse the spring,
I'll break his heart for 'T● had she not a face,
Too tempting for a Jove.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: The graces sat,
On her fair eyelids ever, but his youth
Lusting for change, so doted on a lady,
Fantastic, and yet fair; a piece of wonder:
They call her humour; and her parasite folly,
He cast the sweet spring off, and turned us from him;
Yet his celestial kinsman, for young Raybright
Is the snns darling: knowing his journeying hither
To see thy glorious court, sends me before
To attend on you, and spend all my hours
In care for him —

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: Obey your charge — o thou builder,
Of me thy hand maid! Landlord of my life,
Life of my love, throne where my glories sit;
I ride in triumph on a silver cloud;
Now I but see thee.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Rise; is Raybright come yet.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Be you indulgent over him,
And lavish thou thy treasure —

sp.speaker: Plenty
sp.l: Our princely cousin Raybright,
Your darling, and the world's delight, is come.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Who with them.

sp.speaker: Ple.
sp.l: A goddess in a woman, attended
By a prating saucy fellow, called folly.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: They'll confound him, but he shall run,
Go and receive him.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Your sparkling eyes, and his arrival, draws
Heaps of admirers; earth itself will sweat
To bear our weights; vouchsafe, bright power, to borrow
Winds not too rough from Aeolus, to fan
Our glowing faces

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: I will: ho Aeolus;
Unlock the jail, and lend a wind or two,
To fan my girl the summer.

sp.speaker: Aeo.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: No roarers.

sp.speaker: Aeo.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Quickly.

sp.speaker: Aeo.
sp.l: Fly you slaves, summer sweats; cool her.

div.stage: Enter summer, Raybright, humour, plenty, Folly, country-fellows and wenches.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Hay-makers, rakers, reapers and mowers,
Wait on your summer-queen,
Dress up with musk-rose her eglantine bowers,
Daffodils strew the green,
Sing dance and play
'Tis holy day.
The sun does bravely shine
On our ears of corn.
Rich as a pearl
Coms every girl,
This is mine, this is mine, this is mine;
Let us die, ere away they be born.
Bow to the sun, to our Queen, and that fair one
Come to behold our sparts,
Each bonny lass here is counted a rare one,
As those in prince's courts.
These and we
With country glee
Will teach the woods to resound,
And the hills with echoes hollow:
Skipping lambs
Their bleating dams
Amongst kids shall trip it round,
For joy thus our wenches we follow.
Wind, jolly huntsmen, your neat bugles shrilly,
Hounds make a lusty cry:
Spring up, you falconers, the partridges freely,
Then let your brave hawks fly.
Horses amain
Ever ridg, over plain,
The dogs have the stag in chase;
'Tis a sport to content a King.
So ho ho, through the skies
How the proud bird flies,
And sowcing kills with a grace,
Now the deer falls, hark how they ring. —

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: Leave off, the sun is angry, and has drawn
A cloud before his face ▪

div.stage: The sun by degrees is clouded.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: He is vexed to see
That proud star shine near you, at whose rising
The spring fell sick and died; think what I told you,
His coins will kill you else.

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: It cannot — fair prince!
Though your illustrious name has touched mine ear:
Till now I never saw you, nor never saw
A man whom I more love, more hate,

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Ha lady!

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: For him I love you, from whose glittering rays
you boast your great name, for that name I hate you,
Because you killed my mother, and my nurse.

sp.speaker: Plenty
sp.l: Killed he my grandmother, plenty will never
Hold you byth' hand again.

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: You have free leave
To thrust your arm into our treasury
As deep as I myself: plenty shall wait
Still at your elbow, all my sports are yours,
Attendants yours, my state and glory's yours;
But these shall be as sunbeams from a glass
Reflected on you, not to give you heat
To dote on a smooth face, my spirit's too great,

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Divinest!

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Let her go.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And I'll go after, for I must and will have a fling at one of
Her plum-trees.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I never was scorned till now.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: This is that Alteza,
That Rhodian wonder, gazed at by the sun:
I feared thine eyes should have beheld a face,
The moon has not a clearer, this! A dowdy,

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: An ouzel, this a queen-apple; or a crab she gave you.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: She bids you share her treasure, but who keeps it.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: She points to trees great with child with fruit, but when
Delivered grapes hang in ropes, but no drawing, not a drop of
Wine: whole ears of corn lay their ears together for bread, but
The devil a bit I can touch.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Be ruled by me once more, leave her.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: In scorn, as he does me.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Scorn! If I be not deceived, I ha' seen summer go up and
Down with hot codlings; and that little baggage, her daughter
Plenty, crying six bunches of radish for a penny.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Thou shalt have nobler welcomes, for I'll bring thee
To a brave and bounteous housekeeper, free autumn.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Oh! there's a lad — let's go then.

sp.speaker: Plenty
sp.l: Where's this prince, my mother; for the Indies
Must not have you part —

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Must not?

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: No; must not.
I did but chide thee like a whistling wind
Playing with leavy dancers: when I told thee
I hated thee, I lied; I dote upon thee.
Unlock my garden of th'hesperides,
By dragons kept (The apples being pure gold)
Take all that fruit, 'tis thine.

sp.speaker: Plenty
sp.l: Love but my mother, I'll give thee corn enough to feed
The world.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I need not golden apples, not your corn;
What land soe'er, the world's surveyor, the sun
Can measure in a day, I dare call mine:
All kingdoms I have right to, I am free
Of every country; in the four elements
I have as deep a share as an emperor;
All beasts whom the earth bears are to serve me,
All birds to sing to me, and can you catch me
With a tempting golden apple,

sp.speaker: Plenty
sp.l: She's too good for thee;
When she was born, the sun for joy did rise
Before his time, only to kiss those 〈◊〉,
Which having touched, he stole from them such store
Of light, she shone more bright than e'er before:
At which he vowed, whenever thee did die,
He'd snatch them up, and in his 〈◊〉 sphere
Place them, since she had no two stars so clear.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Let him now snatch them up away.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Away, and leave this Gipsy.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Oh! I am lost.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Love scorned, of no triumph more than love can boast.

sp.speaker: Plenty
sp.l: This strump will confound him.

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: She has me deluded —

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Is Raybright gone.

sp.speaker: Summer
sp.l: Yes, and his spiteful eyes
Have shot darts through me.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Ay, thy wounds will cure,
And lengthen out thy days, his followers gone ▪
Cupid and fortune take you charge of him.
Here thou, my brightest Queen, must end thy reign,
Some nine months hence I'll shine on thee again.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Pamona, Raybright, Cupid and fortune.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Your entertainment, autumn's bounteous Queen,
Have feasted me with rarities as delicate,
As the full growth of an abundant year
Can ripen to my palate.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: They are but courtings
Of gratitude to our dread lord the sun,
From whom thou drawest thy name; the feast of fruits
Our gardens yield, are much too course for thee;
Could we contract the choice of nature's plenty
Into one form, and that form to contain
All delicates, which the wanton sense
Would relish: or desire to invent to please it,
The present were unworthy far to purchase
A sacred league of friendship.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I have rioted
In surfeits of the ear, with various music
Of warbling birds; I have smelled perfumes of roses,
And every flower with which the fresh-trimmed earth
Is mantled in: the spring could mock my senses
With these fine barren lullabies, the summer
Invited my then ranging eyes to look on
Large fields of ripened corn, presenting trifles
Of waterish petty dainties, but my taste
Is only here pleased, tother objects claim
The y●e of formal, these are real bounties,

sp.speaker: Pom
sp.l: 〈◊〉 can transcend thy wishes, whom the creatures
Of every age and quality posts, madding
From land to land, and sea to sea to meet,
Shall wait upon thy nod, fortune and Cupid,
Love yield thy quiver, and thine arrows up
To this great prince of time, before him fortune,

div.l: Power out thy mint of treasures, crown him sovereign
Of what his thoughts can glory to command:
He shall give payment of a royal prize
To fortune, judgement, and to Cupid's eyes.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Be a merchant, I will freight thee
With all store that time is bought for.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Be a lover, I will wait thee
With success in life most sought for.

sp.speaker: Forester
sp.l: Be enamoured on bright honour,
And thy greatness shall shine glorious.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Chastity, if thou smile on her,
Shall grow servile, thou victorious.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Be a warrior, conquest ever
Shall triumphantly renown thee.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Be a courtier, beauty never
Shall but with her duty crown thee.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Fortune's wheel is thine, depose me,
I'm thy slave, thy power hath bound me.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Cupid's shafts are thine, dispose me,
Love loves love, thy graces wound me.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Cup. Live, reign, pi●●e is fame's jewel;
We obey, o! be not cruel.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: You ravish me with infinites, and lay
A bounty of more sovereignty and amazement,
Than the Atlas of mortality can support —

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: What's here.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Nay pray observe.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Be my heart's empress, build your kingdom there.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: With what an earnestness he complies.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Upon my life he means to turn costermonger, and is projecting
How to forestall the market; I shall cry pippins
Rarely.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Till now, my longings were never satisfied,
And the desires my sensual appetite
Were only fed with barren expectations,
To what I now am filled with.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p:
Yes we are filled and must be emptied, these wind fruits have
distended my guts into a lenten pudding, there's no fat in them, my belly swells, but my sides fall away, a month of such diet would make me a living anatomy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: These are too little, more are due to him,
That is the pattern of his father's glory;
Dwell but amongst us, industry shall strive,
To make another artificial nature;
And change all other seasons into ours.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Shall my heart break, I can contain no longer.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: How fares my loved humour?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: A little stirred, no matter, I'll be merry:
Call for some music, do not; I'll be melancholy.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: A sullen humour, and common, in a dicer that has lost all
His money.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Lady! I hope 'tis no neglect of courtesy
In us, that so disturbs you, if it rise
From any discontent, reveal the cause,
It shall be soon removed.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Oh! my heart, help to unlace my gown.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: And unlace your petticoat.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Saucy, how now! 'tis well you have some sweet heart,
Some new fresh sweet heart; I'm a goodly fool to be thus played
On, stalled, and foiled.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Why madam?
We can be courteous without stain of honour;
'Tis not the raging of a lustful blood
That we desire to tame with satisfaction:
Nor hath his masculine graces in our breast
Kindled a wanton fire, our bounty gives him
A welcome free, but chaste and honourable.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.p: Nay 'tis all one, I have a tender heart, come, come, let's drink.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: A humour in fashion with gallants, and brought out of the
Low countries.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Fie! there's no music in thee, let us sing.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Here's humour in the right trim, a few more such toys
Would make the little world of man run mad, as the Puritan
That sold his conscience for a may pole —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: The meaning of this mirth.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: My lord is coming.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Let us attend, to humble our best thanks,
For these high favours —

div.stage: Enter autumn and Baccanalian, humour and Follie.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: My dearest lord, according to th' injunction
Of your command, I have with all observance,
Given entertainment to this noble stranger.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: The sun-born Raybright, minion of my love,
Let us be twins in heart, thy grandsires beames
Shine graciously upon our fruits, and vines:
I am his vassal-servant, tributary:
And for his sake, the kingdoms I possess,
I will divide with thee, thou shalt command
The Lydian Tmolus, and Campanian mounts,
To nod their grape-crowned heads into thy bowls,
Expressing their rich juice: a hundred grains
Both from the Baltic and Sicilian fields,
Shall be congested for thy sacrifice
'In Ceres' fane, Tiber shall pay thee apples,
And Sicyon olives, all the choicest fruits,
Thy father's heat doth ripen.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Make me but treasurer
Of your respected favours, and that honour
Shall equal my ambition.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: My Pomona,
Speed to prepare a banquet of novelties;
This is a day of rest, and worth whiles,
Will sport before our friends, and shorten time
With length of wonted revels.

sp.speaker: Pom.
sp.l: I obey :
Will't please you madam, a retirement
From these extremes in men, more tolerable,
Will better fit our modesties.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I'll drink, and be a Bacchanalian; no, I will not;

div.stage: Enter, I'll follow; stay, I'll go before.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Fe'ne what humour pleaseth.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Raybright, a health to Phoebus — drinks.
These are the paeans which we sing to him,
and ye wear no bays, our cups are only
Crowned with Lyeus' blood, to him a health —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I must pledge that too.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Now one other health
To our grand patron, called, good fellowship;
Whose livery, all our people hereabout
Are called in. —

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I am for that too.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: 'Tis well, let it go round, and as our custom is
Of recreations of this nature, join,
Your voices, as you drink, in lively notes;
Sing Jos unto Bacchus.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Hey ho's, a god of winds, there's at least four and twenty of them imprisoned in my belly; it I sigh not forth some of them, the rest will break out at the back door; and how sweet the music of their roaring will be, let an Irishman judge.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: He is a songster too.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: A very foolish one; my musics natural, and came by inheritance; my father was a French nightingale, and my mother an English wagtail; I was born a cuckoo in the spring, and lost my voice in summer, with laying my eggs in a sparrow's nest; but I'll venture for one, fill my dish; every one take his own, and when I hold up my finger, off with it.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Begin.

sp.speaker: Folly

lg.l: Cast away care, he that loves sorrow,
Lengthens not a day, nor can buy tomorrow:
Money is trash, and he that will spend it,
Let him drink merrily, fortune will send it.
Merrily, merrily, merrily, oho.
Play it off stiffly, we may not part so: merrily etc.
Wine is a charm, it heats the blood too,
Cowards it will arm, if the wine be good too;
Quickens the wit, and makes the back able;
Scorns to submit to the watch or constable.
Merrily, etc.
Plots fly about, give us more liquor;
Brothers of a rout, our brains will flow quicker;
Empty the cask, score up, we care not,
Fill all the pots again, drink on, and spare not,
Merrily, etc.

sp.p: Now have I more air than ten musicians, besides there is a whirlwind in wind in my brains, I could both caper and turn round.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Oh! a dance by all means,
Now cease your healths, and in an active motion
Bestir ye nimbly, to beguile the hours.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: I am for you in that too, 'twill jog down the lees of these rouses into a freer passage; but take heed of sure footing, 'tis a slippery season; many men fall by rising, and many women are raised by falling —

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: How likes our friend this pastime?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Above utterance,
Oh! how have I in ignorance and dullness,
Run through the progress of so many minutes;
Accusing him, who was my life's first author,
Of slackness and neglect, whilst I have dreamt
The folly of my days in vain expense,
Of useless taste and pleasure; pray my lord
Let one health pass about, whilst I be me
What course I am to take, for being denizen
In your unlimited courtesies.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Devise a round,
You have your liberty.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: A health to autumn's self.
And here let time hold still his restless glass,
That not another golden sand may fall
To measure how it passeth.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Continue here with me, and by thy presence
Create me favourite to thy fair progenitor;
And be mine heir.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I want words to express
My thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: Whate'er the wanton spring,
When she doth diaper the ground with beauties,
toils for, comes home to autumn, Summers sweats
●ither in pasturing her furlongs, reaping
The crop of bread, ripening the fruits for food,
Autumns garners house them, autumns jollities
Feeds on them; I alone in every land
Traffic my useful merchandise, gold and jewels,
Lordly possessions, are for my commodities
Mortgaged and los●, 〈◊〉 chief moderator
Between the cheek-parched summer, and th' extremes
Of winter's tedious frost; nay, in myself
I do contain another teeming spring ▪
Surety of health prosperity of life
Belongs to autumn, if thou then canst hope
To inherit immortality in frailty,
Live here 〈◊〉 time be spent, yet be not old.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 the sun, you are the years great emperor.

sp.speaker: Autumn
sp.l: On now, to new variety of feasts;
Princely contents are fit for princely guests, exit —

sp.speaker: Ray ▪
sp.l: My lord I'll follow; sure I am not well.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Surely I am half drunk, or monstrously mistaken, you
Mean to stay here belike.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Whither should I go else?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Nay, if you will kill yourself in your own defence, I'll
Not be of your jury —

sp.speaker: H●.
sp.l: You have had precious pleasures, choice of drunkenness;
Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I feel a war within me,
And every doubt that resolution kills
Springs up a greater in the years revolution;
There cannot be a season more delicious,
When plenty (Summer's daughter) empties daily
Her cornucopia, filled with choicest viands.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.l: Plenty's horn is always full in the city.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: When temperate heat offends not with extremes;
When day and night have their distinguishment
With a more equal measure.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Ha! in contemplation.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Troubling himself with this windy-guts; this bellyaking autumn; this apple John Kent, and warden of fruiterer's hall.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: When the bright sun, with kindly distant beams
Guilds ripened fruit.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: And what fine meditation transports you thus,
You study some encomium
Upon the beauty of the garden's Queen,
You'd make the paleness to supply the vacancy
Of Cinthia's dark defect.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Madam let! But a green sickness chambermaid be thoroughly steeled, if she get not a better colour in one month, I'll be forfeited to autumn for ever, and fruit-eat my flesh into a consumption.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Come Raybright, whatsoever suggestions
Have won on thy apt weakness, leave these empty
And hollow sounding pleasures, that include
Only a windy substance of delight,
Which every 〈◊〉 alters into air:
I'll stay no longer here.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I must.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: You shall not,
These are adulterate mixtures of vain follies; I'll bring thee
Into the court of
Winter, there thy food:
Shall not be sickly fruits, but healthful broths,
Strong meat and dainty.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Pork, beef, mutton, (Very sweet mutton, veal venison, capon, fine fat capon, partridge, snite, plover, larks, teal admirable teal, my lord.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Mystery there, like to another nature,
Confects the substance of the choicest fruits,
In a rich candy, with such imitation
Of form and colour, 'twill deceive the eye:
Until the taste be ravished.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Comfits and caraways, marchpanes and marmalades sugar-plums and poppin-pies, ginger bread and walnuts

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Nor is his bounty limited, he'll not spare
t'exhaust the treasure of a thousand Indies.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Two hundred pound suppers, and neither fiddlers nor broken glasses reckoned, besides, a hundred pound a throw, ten times together, if you can hold out so long.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: You tell me wonders!
Be my conductress, I'll fly this place in secret;
Three quarters of my time is almost spent,
The last remains to crown my full content.
Now if I fail, let man's experience read me;
'Twas humour, joined with folly, did mislead me.

sp.speaker: H●.
sp.l: Leave this naked season,
Wherein the very trees shake off their locks,
It is so poor and barren.

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: And when the hair falls off, I have heard a poet say, 'tis no good sign of a sound body.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Come let's go taste old winter's fresh delights,
And ● well with pleasures our big appetites.
The summer, autumn, and the spring,
As 'twere conjoined in one conjugal ring;
An emblem of four provinces we sway,
Shall all attend our pastimes night and day;
Shall both be subject to our glorious state,
While we enjoy the blessings of our fate:
And since we've notice that some barbarous spirits
Mean to oppose our entrance, if by words
They'll not desist, we'll force our way with swords.

sp.p: Hear you the news neighbour?
Yes, to my grief neighbour; they say our prince Raybright is coming hither, with whole troops and trains of courtiers; we're like to have a fine time on't neighbours.

Our wives and daughters are, for they are sure to get by the bargain, though our barn be emptied, they will be sure to be with barn for't: oh! these courtiers, neighbours, are pestilent
knaves; but ere I'll suffer it, I'll pluck a crow with some of 'em.
Faith neighbour let's lay our heads together, and resolve to die like men, rather than live like beasts.
Ay, like horn-beasts, neighbour; they may talk and call us rebels, but a fig for that, 'tis not a fart matter; let's be true amongst ourselves , and with our swords in hand resist his entrance —

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: What such murmurings does your gall bring forth,
Will you prove't true, no good coms from the North;
Bold saucy mortals, dare you then aspire
With snow and ice to quench the sphere of fire:
Are your hearts frozen like your clime, from thence
All temperate heat's fled of obedience:
How durst you else with force think to withstand
Your prince's entry into this his land;
A prince who is so excellently good,
His virtue is his honour, more than blood;
In whose clear nature, as two suns, do rise
The attributes of merciful, and wise:
Whose laws are so impartial, they must
Be counted heavenly, cause they're truly just:
Who does with princely moderation give
His subjects an example how to live;
Teaching their erring natures to direct
Their wills, to what it ought most to affect:
That as the sun does unto all dispense
Heat, light, nay life from his full influence,
Yet you wild fools, possessed with giant rage,
Dare, in your lawless fury, think to wage
War against heaven, and from his shining throne
Pull Jove himself, for you to tread upon;
Were your heads circled with his own green oak,
Yet are they subject to his thunderstroke;
And he can sink such wretches as rebel,
From heaven's sublime height, into the depth of hell.

sp.p:
The devil a can as soon, we fear no colours, let him do his worst; there's many a tall fellow besides us, will die rather than see his living taken from them, nay even eat up; all things are
grown so dear, there's no enduring more mouths than our own, neighbour.

Thou'rt a wise fellow, neighbour, prate is but prate; they say this prince too would bring new laws upon us, new rights into the temples of our gods, and that's abominable, we'll all be hanged first —

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: A most fair pretence,
To found rebellion upon conscience;
Dull stubborn fools, whose perverse judgements still
Are governed by the malice of your will,
Not by indifferent reason, which to you
Coms, as in droughs the elemental dew
Does on the parched earth, 'Twets, but does not give
Moisture enough to make the plants to live:
Things void of soul, can you conceive that he,
Whose every thought's an act of piety,
Who's all religious, furnished with all good
That ever was comprised in flesh and blood,
Cannot direct you in the fi●●est way
To serve those powers, to which himself does pay
True zealous worship ▪ nay's so near allied
To them, himself must needs be deified —

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: Save you gentlemen! 'tis very cold, you live in frost, you've winter still about you.

sp.l: What are you sir?

sp.speaker: Folly
sp.p: A courtier sir; but you may guess, a very foolish one, to leave the bright beams of my lord, the prince, to travel hither; I have an ague on me, do you not see me shake: well, if our courtiers, when they come hither, have not warm young wenches, good wines, and fires to heat their bloods, 'twill freeze into an apoplexy; farewell frost, I'll go seek a fire to thaw me, I'm all ice I fear already.
Farewell and be hanged, ere such as these shall eat what we have sweated for, we'll spend our bloods; come neighbours, let's go call our company together, and go meet this prince he talks so of.
Some shall have but a sour welcome of it, if my crab ● tree cudgel hold here.

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: 'Tis, I see,
Not in my power to alter destiny:
You're mad in your rebellious minds, but hear
What I presage, with understanding clear:
As your black thoughts are misty, take from me
This as a true and certain augury,
This prince shall come, and by his glorious side
Laurel-crowned conquest shall in triumph ride,
Armed with the justice that attends his cause,
You shall with penitence embrace his laws:
He to the frozen Northern clime shall bring
A warmth so temperate, as shall force the spring
Usurp my privilege, and by his ray
Night shall be changed into perpetual day.
Plenty and happiness shall still increase,
As does his light, and turtle-footed peace
Dance like a fairy through his realms, while all
That envy him shall like swift comets fall,
By their own fire consumed, and glorious he
Ruling, as 'twere, the force of destiny,
Shall have a long and prosperous reign on earth,
Then fly to heaven, and give a new star birth.
sp.stage: Enter Raybright, humour, bounty, winter and delight.
sp.l: But see, our star appears, and from his eye
Fly thousand beams of sparkling majesty.
Bright son of Phoebus! welcome, I begin
To feel the ice fall from my cris●ed skin;
For at your beams the waggoner might thou
His chariot, axled with Rephean snow;
Nay, the slow moving north-star having felt
Your temperate heat, his icicles would melt.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: What bold rebellious caitiffs dare disturb
The happy progress of our glorious peace ▪
Contemn the justice of our equal laws,
Profane those sacred rights, which still must be
Attendant on monarchal dignity.
I came to frolic with you, and to cheer
Your drooping souls by vigour of my beams;
and have I this strange welcome! reverend winter!
I'm come to be your guest; your bounteous free
Condition does assure, I shall have
A welcome entertainment.

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: Illustrious sir! I am ignorant
How much expression my true zeal will want
To entertain you fitly, yet my love,
And hearty duty, shall be far above
My outward welcome, to that glorious light
Of heaven, the sun which chases hence the night;
I am so much a vastaile, that I'll strive,
By honouring you, to keep my faith alive
To him, brave prince, though you, who do inherit
Your father's cheerful heat, and quickening spirit;
Therefore as I am winter, worn and spent
So far with age, I am time's monument;
Antiquities example, in my zeal,
Ay, from my youth, a span of time will steal
To open the free treasures of my court,
And swell your soul with my delights and sport.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Never till now
Did admiration beget in me truly
The rare matched twins at once, pity and pleasure;
So royal, so abundant in earth's blessings,
Should not partake the comfort of those beams,
With which the sun beyond extent doth cheer
The other seasons, yet my pleasures with you,
From their false charms, doth get the start as far
As heaven's great lamp from every minor star.

sp.speaker: Boun.
sp.l: Sir! you can speak well, if your tongue deliver
The message of your heart, without some cu●ing
Of restraint, we may hope to enjoy
The lasting riches of your presence hence,
Without distrust or change

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Winter's sweet bride,
All conquering bounty, Queen of hearts, life's glory,
Nature's perfection; whom all love, all serve;
To whom fortune, even in extreme's a slave,
when I fall from my duty to thy goodness,
Then let me be ranked as nothing.

sp.speaker: Boun.
sp.l: Come you, flatter me.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: I flatter you! Why madam? you are bounty;
Sole daughter to the royal throne of peace.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: He minds not me now.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: Bounty's self!
For you he is no soldier dares not fight,
No scholar he, that dares not plead your merits,
Or study your best sweetness, should the sun,
Eclipsed for many years, forbear to shine
Upon the bosom of our naked pastures,
Yet where you are, the glories of your smiles
Would warm the barren grounds, arm heartless misery,
And cherish desolation. Deed I honour you,
And as all others ought to do, I serve you ▪

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Are these the rare sights, these the promised compliments.

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: Attendance on our revels, let delight
Conjoin the day with sable-footed night;
Both shall forsake their orbs, and in one sphere
Meet in soft mirth, and harmless pleasures here;
While plump Lyeus shall, with garland crowned
Of triumph-ivy, in full cups abound
Of Cretan wine, and shall dame Ceres call
To wait on you, at winter's festival:
While gawdy summer, autumn, and the spring,
Shall to my lord their choicest viands bring.
We'll rob the sea, and from the subtle air,
Fetch her inhabitant, to supply our fare.
That were apecious here, he in one night
Should sate with danties his strong appetite.
Begin our revels then, and let all pleasure
Flow like the ocean, in a boundless measure —

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: Wit and pleasure soft attention,
Grace the sports of our invention.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Conceit peace, for detraction
Hath already drawn a faction,
Shall deride thee.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: Antic leave me;
For in labouring to bereave me
of a scholar's praise, thy dotage: — shall be hissed at.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Here's a hot age;
When such petty penmen covet
Fame by folly, on, I'll prove it
Scurvy by thy par●, and try thee
By thine own wit.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: I defy thee,
Here are nobler judges, wit
Cannot suffer where they sit.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Prithee foolish conceit, leave off thy set-speeches, and come to the conceit if self in plain languages; what goodly thing is't, in the name of laughter?

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: Detraction do thy worst, conceit appears,
In honour of the sun, their fellow-friend,
Before thy censure; know then that the spheres,
Have for a while resigned their orbs, and lend
Their seats to the four elements, who joined
With the four known complexions, have atoned
A noble I ague, and severally put on
Material bodies; here amongst 'em none
Observes a difference; earth and air alike
Are sprightly active; fire and water seek
No glory of pre-eminence; phlegm and blood,
Choler and melancholy, who have stood
In contrarieties, now meet for pleasure,
To entertain time in a courtly measure.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Impossible and improper; first to personate insensible creatures, and next to compound quite opposite humours; fie, fie, fie, it's abominable.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: Fond ignorance! how darest thou vainly scan
Impossibility; what reigns in man
Without disorder; wisely mixed by nature,
To fashion and preserve so high a creature.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Sweet sir! when shall our mortal eyes behold this new
Piece of wonder;
We must gaze on the stars for it doubtless,

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: See, thus the clouds fly off, and run in chase,
When the sun's bounty lends peculiar grace.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Fine i'faith; pretty, and in good earnest; but sirrah scholar; will they come down too?

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: Behold 'em well, the foremost represents
Air, the most sportive of the elements,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: A nimble rascal, I warrant him some alderman's son; wondrous giddy and lightheaded; one that blew his patrimony away in feather and tobacco.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: The next near him is fire.

sp.speaker: Detraction
sp.p: A choleric gentleman, I should know him, a younger brother and a great spender, but seldom or never carries any money about him; he was begotten when the sign was in Taurus, for a rores like a bull, but is indeed a bell-wether.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: The third in rank is water.

sp.speaker: Detraction
sp.p: A phlegmatic cold piece of stuff, his father methinks should be one of the dunce-table, and one that never drunk strong beer in's life but at festival times, and then he caught the heartburning a whole vacation and half a term after.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: The fourth is earth.

sp.speaker: Detraction
sp.p: A shrewd plodding-pated fellow, and a great lover of news; I guess at the rest, blood is placed near air, choler near fire, phlegm and water are sworn brothers, and so are earth and melancholy.

sp.speaker: Conceit
sp.l: Fair nymph of harmony, be it thy task
To sing them down, and rank them in a mask. —

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: See the elements conspire,
Nimble air does court the earth,
Water does commix with fire,
To give our prince's pleasure birth;
Each delight, each joy, each sweet,
In one composition meet.
All the seasons of the year,
Winter does invoke the spring,
Summer does in pride appear,
Autumn forth its fruits doth bring,
And with emulation pay
Their tribute to this holiday;
In which the darling of the sun is come,
To make this place a new elysium.

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: How do these pleasures please?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Pleasures!

sp.speaker: Boun.
sp.l: Live here,
And be my lord's friend, and thy sports shall vary
A thousand ways, invention shall beget
Conceits as curious as the thoughts of change
Can aim at.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Trifles: progress o'er the year
Again my Raybright, therein like the sun,
As he in heaven runs his circular course,
So thou on earth run thine, for to be fed
With stale delights, breeds dulness and contempt;
Think on the spring.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: She was a lovely virgin.

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: My royal lord!
Without offence, be pleased but to afford
Me give you my true figure, do not scorn
My age, nor think, cause I appear forlorn,
I serve for no use, 'tis my sharper breath
Does purge gross exhalations from the earth;
My frosts and snows do purify the air
From choking fogs, makes the sky clear and fair:
And though by nature cold and chill I be,
Yet I 〈◊〉 warm in bounteous charity;
And can, my lord, by grave and sage advice,
Bring you toth' happy shades of paradise.

sp.speaker: Ray.
sp.l: ●hat wonder; oh! can you bring me thither?

sp.speaker: Winter
sp.l: I can direct and point you out a path

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: But where's the guide?
Quicken thy spirits, Raybright, I'll not leave thee,
We'll run the self same race again, that happiness
These lazy, sleeping, tedious winter's nights
Become not noble action.

sp.speaker: Ray
sp.l: To the spring
I am resolved — oh! what strange light appears;
The sun is up sure.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Wanton darling look, and worship with amazement.
Oes! gracious lord.

sp.speaker: Sun.
sp.l: Thy sands are numbered, and thy glass of frailty
〈…〉 out to the last: here in this mirror
Let man behold the circuit of his fortunes;
The 〈◊〉 of the spring dawns like the morning,
Bedewing childhood with unrelished beauties
Of gawdy sights; the summer, as the noon,
Shines in delight of youth, and ripens strength
To autumn's manhood, here the evening grows,
And knits up all felicity in folly;
Winter at last draws on the night of age;
Yet still a humour of some novel fancy
Untasted, or untried, puts off the minute
Of resolution, which should bid farewell
To a vain world of weariness and sorrows.
The powers from whom man does derive his pedigree
Of his creation, with a royal bounty
Give him health, youth, delight for free attendants
To rectify his carriage: to be thankful
Again to them, man should cashier his riots,
His bosom whorish sweetheart, idle humour;
His reasons dangerous seducer, folly; then shall
Like four straight pillars, the four elements
Support the goodly structure of mortality;
Then shall the four complexions, like four heads
Of a clear river, streaming in his body,
Nourish and comfort every vein and sinew.
No sickness of contagion, no grim death
Of deprivation of healths real blessings
Shall then affright the creature built by heaven,
Reserved to immortality, henceforth
In peace go to our altars, and no more
Question the power of supernal greatness,
But give us leave to govern as we please
Nature, and her dominion, who from us,
And from our gracious influence, hath both being
And preservation; no replies but reverence.
Man hath a double guard, if time can win him;
Heaven's power above him, his own peace within him.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
